Carbon nanotubes as advanced catalysts and catalytic supports for the liquid-phase aerobic oxidation of hydrocarbons: A review Shakir Ul Azam ⁎ Orlinska Beata Orlińska Department of Chemical Organic Technology and Petrochemistry, Silesian University of Technology, 44–100 Gliwice, Poland Department of Chemical Organic Technology and Petrochemistry, Silesian University of Technology Gliwice 44–100 Poland Department of Chemical Organic Technology and Petrochemistry, Silesian University of Technology, 44–100 Gliwice ⁎ Corresponding author. The liquid-phase aerobic oxidation of hydrocarbons to more valuable oxygenized compounds is among the most crucial industrial processes. Traditionally, these processes were executed by using a stoichiometric amount of various toxic oxidants with homogeneous catalysts of transition-metal salts and complexes, which results in the production of a gigantic amount of corrosive and noxious waste. Recently, carbon nanotubes have gained momentous importance as catalysts and catalytic support in various chemical processes because of their unprecedented properties. Few researchers have actually employed carbon nanotubes and functionalized carbon nanotubes as catalysts and catalytic support for the liquid-phase aerobic oxidation of hydrocarbons. This review specifically focused on the use of carbon nanotubes and functionalized carbon nanotubes as catalysts and catalytic supports in the liquid-phase aerobic oxidation of hydrocarbons. A plausible mechanism of the reaction has also been drawn while thoroughly reviewing the previously reported data. The impact of impurities in carbon nanotubes on their catalytic activity for the liquid-phase aerobic oxidation of hydrocarbons has also been discussed. It is observed from the literature that oxygenated carbon nanotubes have a negative effect on their catalytic activity for the liquid-phase aerobic oxidation of hydrocarbons, while nitrogen doping and/or metal nanoparticle immobilization, the surface electron transfer between the modified carbon nanotubes and radicals enhanced and improved the catalytic activity. Furthermore, the nitrogen-doped and/or metal-nanoparticle-incorporated carbon nanotubes accelerate the decomposition of hydroperoxides, which are key intermediates in the liquid-phase aerobic oxidation of hydrocarbons, thereby improving the overall catalytic activity. Toluene, ethylbenzene, and p-xylene, for instance, oxidize to their respective oxygenated products at the rates of around 9 × 104, 5 × 106, and 3 × 107 tons per year, respectively [2]. The oxidation-based products from hydrocarbon oxidation can later be used in the production of adhesives, cosmetics, paints, rubber, fabrics, detergents, and agrochemicals [3]. Transition-metal salts and complexes [4,5] have been employed as catalysts in these processes, however, the conditions required are harsh and have poor selectivity. Furthermore, caustic promoters such as bromide anions were sometimes also used in addition to the catalyst. These techniques also have several drawbacks, such as the difficulty in separating homogeneous catalysts and the fact that the catalysts are nonreusable and the processes produce huge amounts of waste. Traditional toxic metal oxides [6], peroxides such as tert-butylhydroperoxide [7] or hydrogen peroxide [8,9], and ozone [10] are used as an oxidant in the oxidation processes. However, molecular oxygen is an atom-economical and greener alternative compared to these oxidants [11]. In addition, organic solvents are also often introduced into reaction systems, which pose major challenges with product separation and catalyst recovery, as well as substantially increasing the cost [12–15]. Consequently, a more economical, environmentally friendly, and effective heterogeneous catalytic system using dioxygen as an oxidant is desired without the use of toxic solvents. In recent times, carbon nanotubes (CNTs) have emerged as a promising substitute to traditional catalysts and catalytic supports owing to their remarkable properties, for example, elevated chemical, thermal and mechanical stability, high specific surface area, excellent electrical conductivity, tunable metal-support interaction, tunable chemical functionality (such as nitrogen or boron doped), corrosion resistance, economical, and environmental friendliness [16–18]. CNTs are a one-dimensional material and an allotropic form of carbon that exhibits sp2 hybridization. They differ from other allotropes of carbon, such as two-dimensional graphene and three-dimensional fullerenes and buckyballs, in both structural configuration and properties. CNTs are rolled-up sheets of graphene and can vary in size and structure by the number of graphene sheets on their side walls. Therefore, CNTs can be single-walled (SWCNTs) consisting of a single graphene nanotube or multiwalled (MWCNTs) consisting of several concentric interlinked graphene nanotubes ( Fig. 1) and can have a length-to-diameter ratio greater than 1000,00 [19]. The catalytic activity of pristine and functionalized CNTs has been extensively studied for various reactions including wet air oxidation [20–23], oxidative dehydrogenation [24–26], decomposition [27–30], Friedel-Crafts [31,32], Fischer-Tropsch [33–35], dehydrogenation [36,37], and oxidation of alcohols [38–41] and hydrocarbons [42–46]. Several review articles have focused on the synthesis of CNTs [47–49], functionalization and their catalytic activity [16,50,51], but to date, none of the reviews specifically focused on solvent and/or solvent-free aerobic oxidation of hydrocarbons catalyzed by CNTs and modified CNTs. This review will spotlight the mechanism and catalytic activity of pristine and functionalized CNTs for the liquid-phase solvent and/or solvent-free oxidation of hydrocarbons while focusing on the green oxidation reactions where molecular oxygen has been used as an oxidant. 2 Reaction mechanism 2.1 General reaction mechanism The liquid-phase aerobic oxidation of hydrocarbons involved a radical chain reaction mechanism and followed the following reactions from 1 to 9 [4,52,53]. (1) Initiation : RH + initiator → R • + H − initiator (2) Propagation : R • + O 2 → ROO • (3) ROO • + RH → ROOH + R • (4) ROOH → RO • + OH • (5) RO • + RH → ROH + R • (6) • OH + RH → H 2 O + R • (7) Termination : ROO • + ROO • → ROH + R ′ = O + O 2 (8) ROO • + R • → ROOR (9) R • + R • → R − R The variable valence metal catalysts, for example, iron, copper, cobalt, and manganese, promote the oxidation reactions by accelerating the homolytic decomposition of hydroperoxides into radicals that initiate the chain reactions (10 and 11) [4]. (10) ROOH + Co II → RO • + Co III + HO − (11) ROOH + Co III → ROO • + Co II + H + (12) Net Reaction : ROOH → Co II / Co III RO • + ROO • + H 2 O 2.2 Reaction mechanism over CNTs The aerobic oxidation of hydrocarbons in the liquid phase, for example, ethylbenzene over CNTs as a catalyst produces 1-phenylethyl hydroperoxide (PEHP), acetophenone (AcPO), 1-phenylethyl alcohol (PEA), benzaldehyde (BA), and benzoic acid (BzA) ( Scheme 1). Hydrocarbon oxidation in the presence of oxygen as an oxidant, induced a free radical chain reaction mechanism [54–57], as did ethylbenzene [42,58–61]. The plausible reaction mechanism for the liquid-phase aerobic oxidation of ethylbenzene using CNTs as a catalyst in the presence of dioxygen as an oxidant has been developed and presented in Scheme 2. Initially, ethylbenzene was adsorbed on CNTs' surface and possibly activated by weakening the α-C-H bond in ethylbenzene due to the π-π interaction among CNTs and ethylbenzene. Subsequently, a nearby adsorbed O2 molecule abstracts a weakly bounded α-H atom in ethylbenzene, producing the phenylethyl radical (PE) and the HOO• radical [42]. Some data from the literature suggested that oxygen is involved in oxidation reactions in a simple molecular form (O2) [2,42,62], while others implied that it gets an electron to form the superoxide radical anion (•O2 -) with the help of CNTs [58,63]. In this mechanism, molecular oxygen is considered in the reaction, so in the next step, the produced PE reacts quickly with nearby O2 to produce the 1-phenylethylperoxyl radical (PEPO). PEPO can abstract a hydrogen atom from the α-H bond of ethylbenzene, producing 1-phenylethyl hydroperoxide and PE, where 1-phenylethyl hydroperoxide is the key intermediate in ethylbenzene oxidation and the main chain propagator [42]. This is a cyclic process according to Lin et al. [58], as illustrated in Scheme 2, as the produced PE reacts again with O2 and produces PEPO, and the cycle continues. According to Luo et al. [42] in the next step, PEPO removes the weak α-H atom of 1-phenylethyl hydroperoxide due to the greater reactivity of the C-H bond in 1-phenylethyl hydroperoxide than the secondary C-H bond of ethylbenzene. At the same time, 1-phenylethyl hydroperoxide rapidly converts to acetophenone via the production of hydroxyl radicals (•OH) on CNTs. The produced •OH radicals can abstract the α-H atom of adjacent ethylbenzene and produce fresh PE, which can then be combined with O2 to produce PEPO. PEPO interacts quickly with nearby 1-phenylethyl hydroperoxide again, producing acetophenone and the •OH radical, and the cycle repeats. 1-phenylethyl hydroperoxide can also react with PE, producing 1-phenylethyl alcohol and 1-phenylethyloxy radical (PEO). Benzaldehyde is formed due to subsequent cleavage of β-C-C in PEO and benzaldehyde can further react with O2 to produce benzoic acid [64,65]. 3 Pristine CNTs as metal-free catalysts Pristine CNTs, both SWCNTs, and MWCNTs have proven to be intensely active, selective, and robust metal-free catalysts for hydrocarbon oxidation reactions. CNTs play a vital role in hydrocarbon oxidation reactions via propagating radical chain reactions. CNTs can efficiently promote the reaction flux in solvent cages, leading to increased efficiency in the formation of ketone and alcohol products. CNTs can facilitate electron transfer among radicals and themselves at the solid-liquid interface, augmenting the efficiency of the cage reaction [66]. Studies revealed that sp2 carbons such as graphene and CNTs exhibited superior catalytic activity compared to sp3 carbons (diamond). The superior activity of sp2 carbons was attributed to their capability to catalyze the decomposition of intermediate peroxides, which ultimately enhanced hydrocarbon oxidation reactions [67]. Electron transfer in graphene sheets is a crucial factor in determining the catalytic activity of CNTs in the liquid phase oxidation of hydrocarbons. In pristine CNTs, the delocalized electrons on the surface of graphene sheets facilitate a π-π interaction among radicals and peroxides with themselves [68] and therefore accelerate the decomposition of intermediate peroxides into free radicals. For example, Luo et al. [42] demonstrated that CNTs exhibited an exceptional metal-free catalyst in the liquid phase selective oxidation of ethylbenzene to acetophenone employing dioxygen as an oxidant. Their results indicated that the decomposition of 1-phenylethyl hydroperoxide to acetophenone was facilitated by π-π interactions among peroxide radicals and graphene layers of CNTs. The conversion of ethylbenzene was 38.2% with a selectivity of 60.9% to acetophenone. The activity was comparable to that of other metal-based catalysts under the same conditions. Furthermore, the CNTs were found to be recyclable and retained their activity for all six cycles without any changes in morphology. In a later study, researchers explored the use of commercial-grade CNTs as a catalyst for low-temperature aerobic oxidation of cumene [43]. After optimizing the reaction conditions, they achieved an impressive conversion of cumene (24.1%) with a selectivity of 88.4% for cumene hydroperoxide (CHP). Their finding suggested that the elevated activity of the CNTs was attributed to the delocalized electrons on graphene sheets of CNTs and their capability to catalyze the intermediate cumene hydroperoxide to free radicals. To test the recyclability of CNTs, they separated the CNTs after each run from the reaction mixture and washed them repeatedly with deionized water and ethanol. The results showed that cumene conversion and cumene hydroperoxide selectivity remained consistent over five cycles, indicating that the CNTs were stable and recyclable. The catalytic activities of pristine CNTs have been compared with functionalized CNTs and metal-based catalysts in Table 1. 4 Functionalized CNTs as catalysts and catalytic supports 4.1 Heteroatom-doped CNTs as metal-free catalysts The surface chemistry of CNTs plays a crucial role in many chemical reactions, including hydrocarbon oxidation reactions. The electrical properties of CNTs can be modified and enhanced via heteroatom doping, such as oxygen, nitrogen, phosphorus, sulfur, or boron, which can change their catalytic activity. Doping heteroatoms, for example, nitrogen in CNTs improves the interaction between intermediate radicals and surface carbon, which enhances their catalytic performance [66,69–71]. Furthermore, nitrogen (N) doping can also accelerate the decomposition of intermediate peroxides, ultimately enhancing the catalytic activity [44,72,73]. For instance, Gao et al. concluded that nitrogen incorporated into sp2-hybridized carbon was a crucial factor for the activation of the C-H bond in the reaction. Doped nitrogen did not contribute to the reactant activation; rather, it altered the electronic structure of the neighboring carbon atoms and enhanced their reactivity. This was the major factor that the N-dopant catalyst performed quite well in the oxidation reactions. Furthermore, an increase in the amount of nitrogen at the graphitic sites of the catalysts was noted to increase subsequent catalytic performance [74]. Yu et al. [68] reported the remarkable performance of MWCNTs and nitrogen-doped CNTs (N-CNTs) in the liquid phase aerobic oxidation of cyclohexane. Notably, their results showed that the activity of CNTs synthesized via the chemical vapor deposition (CVD) method was superior even without post-treatment, resulting in a reduction of the practical catalyst cost. The cyclohexane conversion was 34.3% with 52.4% selectivity towards adipic acid. N-CNTs were prepared using the CVD method with aniline as the source of nitrogen and carbon. The nitrogen content and proportion of pyridinic nitrogen increased during the formation of N-CNTs in an ammonia atmosphere, which may have contributed to the enhanced catalytic performance. The produced N-CNTs had a nitrogen-to-carbon ratio of 4.5% after being purified with HCl, and their shape resembled bamboo nanofilament. The BET surface area of the N-doped CNTs was 2–2.4 times greater than that of the undoped CNTs. The catalytic activities of the pristine CNTs and N-CNTs were assessed under the same reaction conditions. The N-CNTs displayed elevated catalytic activity with 45.3% cyclohexane conversion and were more selective toward adipic acid (59.7%) compared to pristine CNTs because the doped nitrogen facilitated electron transfer in the graphene sheet. The catalytic activity of the N-CNTs was higher than that of the metal-based catalysts even at a lower temperature (125 °C). Furthermore, the N-CNTs were recyclable and remained active for all five cycles. The comparison of the catalytic activities of heteroatom-doped CNTs with pristine CNTs and metal-based catalysts is made in Table 1. Cao et al. [44] studied the catalytic activity of CNTs doped with nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), and boron (B) for the aerobic oxidation of cyclohexane in the liquid phase. All three heteroatom-doped CNTs were synthesized using the CVD method with xylene as the carbon source. Aniline-NH3, triphenylphosphine, and triethyl borate were used as precursors for N, P, and B, respectively. The N content of the synthesized N-CNTs ranged from 0% to 4.46%, while the P content of the synthesized P-CNTs ranged from 0.55% to 5.14%. The authors observed that N-CNTs and P-CNTs were active catalysts, while B-doped CNTs were not active catalysts for cyclohexane oxidation. The highest mass normalized activity was obtained for N-CNT (761 mmol g−2 h−1) for the N-CNTs produced aniline in an NH3 environment, while the highest surface area normalized activity was obtained for P-CNTs (28 mmol m−2 h−1) for the CNTs produced from triphenylphosphine in an argon atmosphere. The authors also studied the work function as an indicator of electron donation on carbon and observed that the specific activity of N- and P-doped CNTs relied exponentially on the work function. This suggests that surface electron transfer on CNTs plays a crucial role in cyclohexane oxidation. The catalytic activities of N-CNTs and P-CNTs were higher than some of the metal-based catalysts. Yang et al. [63] unveiled the interaction between radicals and CNTs in cyclohexane oxidation by utilizing in situ electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR). The authors technically confirmed the C6H11 •, C6H11OO•, and O2 • radicals for the first time. The efficient formation of active radicals at the preliminary stage of the reaction was observed over the N-doped MWCNTs, depicting that N-doped MWCNTs were much more effective catalysts than pristine MWCNTs. CNTs and N-CNTs have been studied as metal-free catalysts for the aerobic oxidation of cyclohexene in the liquid phase (80 °C, 1 MPa, 4 h). N-doped CNTs were produced by employing the CVD technique using aniline as the carbon source and xylene as the nitrogen source. N-doped CNTs exhibited exceptional performance for cyclohexane oxidation with 59% conversion and 620.1 mm g−1 h−1 mass-normalized activity. The rate of conversion of cyclohexene per gram of catalyst over N-CNTs was almost six times higher than pristine CNTs while competing with many state-of-the-art metal catalysts. The elevated catalytic performance of N-CNTs was attributed to their capability to promote chain propagation. Recyclability data showed that N-CNTs were stable and recyclable [73]. Liao et al. researched the use of CNTs and N-CNTs for the oxidation of cumene in the liquid phase employing dioxygen as an oxidant. They discovered that N-CNTs significantly accelerated the decomposition of cumene hydroperoxide, consequently increasing the cumene conversion with higher selectivities towards acetophenone and 2-benzyl-2-propanol. The cumene conversion over N-CNTs with 3.33 atom% of nitrogen was almost 4.6 times higher (74.7%) compared to pristine CNTs (16.1%) under similar reaction conditions (80 °C, 0.101 MPa, and 8 h). The nitrogen content in the N-CNTs was also studied by increasing the atom percent of nitrogen. The conversion of the N-CNTs increased as the nitrogen atom percent was increased up to 3.33 atom% above this loading the conversion decreased marking it as the optimal loading. The doping of nitrogen into the CNTs modified the surface electron structure, which finely tuned the reactivity and selectivity. Furthermore, N-CNTs were found to be recyclable for up to four cycles [62]. Mu et al. [75] performed a kinetic study on the utilization of CNTs and N-CNTs in the aerobic oxidation of cumene to investigate the impact of N-doping. The authors thoroughly analyzed the observed time-dependent concentration profiles, developed a kinetic model depending on the mechanism of radical reactions, and produced rate constants and activation energies for each elementary reaction involved in the oxidation process. When the kinetic properties of CNTs and N-CNTs were examined, N-CNTs significantly boosted all elementary reactions, particularly the breakdown of peroxides into active radicals such as RO• and HO•. Furthermore, N-CNTs increased the rate of cumene oxidation and improved the interaction between O2, RO•, RO2 •, and catalyst. Their study also showed that N-CNTs enhanced the production of ketones and alcohols with more alcohol obtained over N-CNTs compared to CNTs. Su et al. [76] researched the effect of N-CNTs dose on their catalytic performance for ethylbenzene aerobic oxidation (155 °C, 1.5 MPa, 4 h). N-CNT activity was increased at lower doses but decreased at higher levels. Mechanistic studies and DFT calculations indicated that doping N atoms into the CNTs impedes the concept of α-H from ethylbenzene molecules, which halts the preliminary radical propagation stage and reduces overall activity. Tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) was utilized as a dual oxidant to boost the catalytic activity of N-CNTs by eliminating the preliminary propagation stage. When TBHP was combined with O2 as an oxidant and a modest dose of N-CNTs, the maximum conversion (46%) was achieved with a selectivity of 72% to acetophenone. However, the authors believe that more investigation is required to properly understand the influence of N-CNTs on ethylbenzene oxidation. Nitrogen atoms that are linked to carbons can have different bonding configurations, for example, pyrrolic N, pyridinic N, graphitic N, and N-oxides species [77–79], as shown in Fig. 2. As a result, it is crucial to recognize the active sites of nitrogen-linked to carbons to better understand the catalytic processes that occur over them. For example, graphitic N-carbons are effective in the aerobic selective oxidation of benzylic alcohols under moderate conditions [80], whereas pyridinic N-carbons are suitable for cathodic oxygen reduction reactions under acidic conditions [81]. Fu et al. [46] studied the activity of N-CNTs to oxidize styrene employing tert-butyl hydroperoxide as an oxidant. They found that the oxidation reaction was enhanced when the N content in the N-CNTs was below 3.51%. However, for a higher N content, a decrease in activity was observed. Surprisingly, the catalytic activity was even worse with a N content increased up to 7.51% compared to the 0.98% N content in the CNTs. Through DFT calculations, the researchers discovered that graphitic N and pyrrolic N can have different functions. For example, graphitic N was an active site for the oxidation reaction of styrene, while pyrrolic N was more effective in producing active oxygen species (HOO•). Cao et al. studied the performance of CNTs and N-CNTs as metal-free catalysts for the epoxidation of α-pinene utilizing dioxygen as a terminal oxidant (80 °C, 1.5 MPa, 4 h). Epoxidation of α-pinene was significantly improved over CNTs with the highest epoxidation/allylic product ratio. The performance of N-CNTs was exceptional, showing 54.5% conversion of α-pinene and a normalized mass activity of 272.4 mmol g−1 h−1, comparable to metal catalysts. The conversion of α-pinene was almost 2.2 times higher than the pristine CNTs. The catalytic stability of N-CNTs was evaluated over five cycles. The N-CNTs were washed repeatedly with deionized water and acetone and then dried after each cycle. Recyclability data showed that N-CNTs were stable and recyclable, as no significant changes were observed for both conversion and product distributions [82]. 4.2 Oxygenated CNTs CNT surface structure has a considerable impact on oxidation reactions. The introduction of oxygen-containing functional groups onto the surface of CNTs, such as carboxyl group, phenol, ketone, ether, lactone, acid anhydride, and so on ( Fig. 3), enables research the effect of these groups on the catalytic activities of CNTs and CNTs-based catalysts in hydrocarbon oxidation processes. Recent research has demonstrated that functionalized CNTs containing oxygen-functional groups exhibit significant activity in the oxidative dehydrogenation of light alkanes [99,100] and ethylbenzene [101,102]. Other studies have postulated that ketonic functional groups (CO) and hydroxyl/quinone functional groups in CNTs could serve as active sites for hydrocarbon oxidative dehydrogenation processes [103,104]. However, because liquid-phase hydrocarbon oxidation processes are more complex than oxidative dehydrogenation reactions, the catalytic activity of CNTs functionalized with oxygen-containing functional groups remains equivocal. Yu et al. studied the activity of oxidized CNTs in the aerobic oxidation of cyclohexane and found that introducing oxygenated functional groups into CNTs negatively affects their catalytic activity. This decrease in activity could be attributed to electron localization caused by the incorporation of oxygenated groups in the CNTs. This localization of electrons is detrimental to the π-π interaction among radicals and graphene layers of oxidized CNTs, which hinders their catalytic performance [68]. Subsequent research studies also demonstrated that these oxygenated groups harmed the catalytic performance of aerobic oxidation of hydrocarbons such as ethylbenzene to acetophenone [42], cumene to cumene hydroperoxide [43] and cyclohexane to cyclohexanone [73]. Chi et al. examined the impact of surface defects and oxygen-containing functional groups on CNTs on the aerobic oxidation of cumene. The authors discovered that oxidized CNTs inhibited cumene oxidation by disclosing the associated mechanism. The oxygenated CNTs might operate as free radical quenchers, trapping the reaction's free radical intermediates, preventing the transfer of the free radical chain, and diminishing the reaction's overall performance. However, surface defects in CNTs are found to have less impact on their catalytic activity compared to functional groups containing oxygen [105]. Other reasons that make the oxygen-containing functional groups on CNTs unsuitable for aerobic oxidation of hydrocarbons in the liquid phase are, (i) the presence of these functional groups alters the surface wettability of the CNTs, rendering them more polar and hydrophilic. Consequently, they become unsuitable for hydrocarbon adsorptions, which are inherently nonpolar in nature [106,107]. (ii) These functional groups could increase diffusion resistance; as a result, the availability and affinity of CNTs surfaces are reduced for organic molecules [107–109]. Table 2 compares the catalytic activity of oxygenated CNTs for the liquid-phase aerobic oxidation of various hydrocarbons. It is observed that increasing the amount of different oxygen-containing functional groups on the surface of CNTs reduces their catalytic activity. However, annealing these oxygenated CNTs can decompose the oxygen-containing functional groups and repair the defects while restoring their catalytic activity. 4.3 Metal, metal oxides, and complex functionalized CNTs The catalytic activity of a catalyst in the liquid-phase hydrocarbon oxidation reactions is usually dominated by the surface electron transfer of the solid catalysts [44,110]. The catalytic performance of CNTs in hydrocarbon oxidation reactions can be further improved by improving electron transfer through the incorporation of metals, for example, Fe, Co, Mn, etc. [111–113]. Furthermore, metallic salts of Cu(II), Co(II), Mn(II) [114], metal oxides such as Mn3O4 [115], MnO2 [116], and metal complexes such as Pt and Pd pincer complexes [117], Mn (III) porphyrins [118], among others, can also be used to improve catalytic activity. These metals, metallic salts, metal oxides, and complexes can be incorporated with CNTs covalently or noncovalently. It is also known that these metals and metallic compounds in the hydrocarbon oxidation reaction accelerate the decomposition of hydroperoxides, which are the key intermediates in the hydrocarbon oxidation reactions, to alcohols and ketones, thereby increasing the catalytic activity [119–123]. Moreover, some research work reported that catalytic activity increased substantially due to the incorporation of metal nanoparticles within CNTs as shown in Fig. 4, so-called encapsulated or confined metal nanoparticles in CNTs [124,125] or bonding to carbons via metal-nitrogen-carbon (M-N-C) bond [113,126,127]. Further research suggested that there is a synergistic effect between metal nanoparticles and CNTs [58,128]. The catalytic activities of CNTs and N-CNTs with metal-modified CNTs have been tabulated in Table 3. The graphene layers in CNTs create nanochannels that range in diameter from less than one nanometer to one hundred nanometers. These unique channels provide a highly confined environment for catalytic reactions and nanocatalysts [129]. The confinement of metal nanoparticles in CNTs has already been recognized as an excellent catalyst in many reactions, including hydrocarbon oxidation reactions [130]. The enhancement in the catalytic performance was due to the confinement of metal nanocatalysts in the CNTs, leading to a unique interaction between metal and the CNTs, thanks to the deformed sp2 hybridization electronic configuration of graphene walls. This peculiarity from planarity causes a shift in π-electron density from the concave inner to the convex outer surface, consequently, an electron-deficient interior and an electron-enriched exterior while leaving the outer surface area unchanged [124]. Studies have revealed that increasing the mobility of electrons in CNTs improves their catalytic activity [68]. Taking into account the aforementioned strategy, Yang et al. [110] investigated the catalytic activity of confined iron (Fe) nanowires in CNTs for cyclohexane aerobic oxidation. Their Fe-filled CNTs have proved an effective catalyst in oxidation reactions with unprecedented performance for a 19.0 wt% loading of Fe. Above this loading surface defects were formed that hinder electron transfer and reduced the activity. Additionally, they studied the dependency of the specific activity of the oxidation reaction over the Fe encapsulated CNTs on the work function, which revealed that a decrease in work function exponentially increase the specific activity. Because of the confined Fe in CNTs, they exhibit high magnetic saturation, facilitating easy separation from the reaction mixture. Their recyclability experiment revealed that the Fe-filled CNTs were stable and could be recycled without loss in the activity. Luo et al. [112] also demonstrated that iron nanowire-filled CNTs (Fe@CNTs) as an active catalyst for the selective aerobic oxidation of ethylbenzene to acetophenone in the liquid phase. The augmented activity was due to the improved electron transfer that arose from the confinement of nanowires in the CNTs. An exceptional activity was obtained with 17.3 wt% of CNTs filled with Fe nanowires. However, with an increase in Fe content from 17.3 wt% to 21.8 wt%, activity was reduced, indicating that an increase in Fe loading in CNTs could create defects that reduce conductivity or an increase in the Fe@CNTs work function, suppressing charge transfer. Furthermore, their results indicated that Fe@CNTs accelerated the decomposition of hydroperoxides to acetophenone due to the improved electron transfer from Fe nanowires to CNTs, which ultimately enhanced the conversion rate. Fe@CNTs were effortlessly retrieved from the reaction system by simply employing an external magnet and reused. The results confirmed that Fe@CNTs were active and stable in all six cycles with no substantial loss in the catalytic activity. Researchers have indicated that encapsulated metal nanoparticles could accelerate the decomposition of hydroperoxides, which is a crucial intermediate product, into acetophenone and certainly contribute to a substantial improvement in catalyst performance by augmenting the electron transfer from metal nanoparticles to CNTs [111]. Furthermore, it has been observed that this electron transport in CNTs might result in a high electron density and a drop in local work functions on the carbon surface [110,112], therefore, accelerating hydroperoxides decomposition through π–π interaction among hydroperoxides and graphene sheets, thus improving the overall conversion rate. Shi et al. researched the catalytic activity of cobalt nanoparticles filled into CNTs as nanoreactors for styrene epoxidation utilizing dioxygen as an oxidant (100 °C, 0.101 MPa, 1 h). For comparison, they also adsorbed cobalt on the surface of the nanotubes ( Fig. 5) and tested the activity for the same reaction. The nanoreactors (Co@CNTs(in)) demonstrated remarkable catalytic performance in the epoxidation of styrene with a conversion rate of over 99% and an epoxide selectivity of 93% during a one-hour reaction. The product yield of the nanoreactors was 93%, compared to a yield of only 50% for Co adsorbed on CNTs surface ((Co@CNTs(out)). Additionally, they used an external magnet to separate the nanoreactors and recycled them for up to three cycles. Nanoreactors performed remarkably well throughout the cycles without diminishing their catalytic activity [131]. Cobalt encapsulated in graphitic N-doped CNT (Co@CGNs) has also been demonstrated to have efficient catalytic activity in the solvent-free aerobic oxidation of ethylbenzene ( Fig. 6). The optimized catalyst demonstrated remarkable activity, converting 68.1% of ethylbenzene with a selectivity of 93.2% acetophenone. Furthermore, the catalyst performed remarkably well in the oxidation of various arylalkane substrates. The increase in catalytic activity was credited to the synergistic effect between metallic Co and graphitic N-doped CNTs [58]. Xiang et al. investigated the effect of nitrogen doping on the catalytic activity of cobalt-encapsulated CNTs for the selective oxidation of arylalkanes. The synthesized catalyst achieved dramatic catalytic activity for ethylbenzene, displaying 78.3% conversion and 93.8% selectivity toward acetophenone. The catalyst also performed exceptionally well in the oxidation of other alkyl aromatic hydrocarbons. Their results showed that the nitrogen source is crucial for the growth of bamboo-shaped CNTs, and Co-Nx in Co@NCNTs-X were the active sites, owing to the synergetic effect between pyridinic N and metallic cobalt [128]. The enhanced catalytic activity of cobalt-encapsulated N-CNTs can be credited to the formation of a coordination structure between Co and pyridinic N (Co-Nx). This coordination structure stabilizes the cobalt nanoparticles and impedes their agglomeration, thereby facilitating their dispersion. Furthermore, the interaction of Co nanoparticles with the pyridinic N of N-CNTs alters the spin, charge, and π state densities of carbon atoms, activating additional carbon atoms and producing more active sites. Consequently, facilitate the adsorption and desorption of intermediates thereby improving the catalytic activity [132–135]. The reaction mechanism for ethylbenzene oxidation, catalyzed by CNTs and cobalt confined within CNTs (Co@CNTs), was elucidated through empirical and kinetic modeling. Co@CNTs showed higher activity in the oxidation reaction compared to pristine CNTs because of their enhanced interfacial charge transfer. The homolytic cleavage of phenylethyl hydroperoxide was discovered to be the rate-determining and fundamental step in the synthesis of acetophenone, which was augmented over Co@CNTs. The simulation results of ethylbenzene oxidation revealed that acetophenone production dominated the reaction route because the addition of acetophenone into the reaction system had very little effect on the reaction rate. While the inclusion of phenylethyl alcohol diminished the oxidation process, apparently due to the prevention of the generation of RO• and phenylethyl alcohol. This restricted hydroperoxide decomposition and reduced overall catalytic performance [136]. Alcohol additives impede the radical process of aerobic oxidation of hydrocarbons, as has been seen in other reactions, as alcohol quenches radicals and prevents their propagation [137–140]. Peckh et al. [114] studied the catalytic activity of transition metal salts of cobalt (Co(II)), copper (Cu(II)), and manganese (Mn(II)) on carboxylated MWCNTs for solvent-free aerobic oxidation of ethylbenzene. The cocatalyst was N-hydroxyphthalimide (NHPI), while the radical initiator was azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN). The Cu(II) immobilized carboxylated MWCNTs exhibited the highest activity (27% conversion to ethylbenzene, 66% selectivity toward acetophenone) compared to those Co(II) and Mn(II) functionalized CNTs. Chen et al. synthesized a Co@N/Co-CNT catalyst for the liquid phase solvent-free selective aerobic oxidation of toluene to benzoic acid. The catalyst consisted of cobalt-encapsulated and atomically scattered CoN4 species inserted in N-CNTs. The catalyst performed remarkably with 33.5% toluene conversion and 91.6% selectivity toward benzoic acid. Reactions were performed without the addition of a radical initiator, while CoN4 species were recognized as active sites in the catalyst [141]. Machado et al. incorporated Pt and Pd pincer complexes on superparamagnetic CNTs and investigated their catalytic activity for solvent-free aerobic oxidation of cyclohexane. The Pt and Pd pincer complexes were covalently immobilized on magnetic SWCNTs functionalized with NH2. Maximum catalytic activity was obtained for the Pd pincer complex-based catalyst with 22.86% conversion and 93.3% selectivity [117]. The catalytic activity of transition metal oxides (TMOs), for example, MnO2, Fe2O3, Cr2O3 [123], MnCO3 [142], Mn3O4 [143,144], and MnO2 [116], has been investigated for liquid oxidation processes. Their variable valence electron pair contributes to their elevated catalytic activity and reducibility. Feng et al. immobilized Mn3O4 nanoparticles in CNTs and investigated their activity for the oxidation of toluene to benzyl alcohol and benzaldehyde in solvent free environment while using dioxygen as an oxidant, and tert-butyl hydroperoxide radical initiator. Their results showed that the immobilized Mn3O4 nanoparticles in the CNTs performed quite well with 24.63% toluene conversion and 90.49% selectivity towards benzyl alcohol and benzaldehyde. The activity was higher compared to both Mn3O4 and CNTs. Furthermore, the catalyst was stable and recyclable [115]. Deng et al. used CNTs as a support for MnO2 nanoparticles to combine the synergistic effect of CNTs and metal oxides for the aerobic oxidation of cumene. A conversion of 73.44% for cumene was achieved with a 59.06% selectivity towards 2-phenyl-2-propanol (PP) using 21.23-MnO2/CNTs. This is considerably greater than the catalytic activity obtained for CNTs and MnO2 separately. The introduction of MnO2 nanoparticles in CNTs improved the decomposition of cumene hydroperoxide, which was further confirmed by DFT calculations [145]. It has been elucidated from the literature that the oxygen-containing functional groups in CNTs harm their catalytic activity due to the localization of electrons following the introduction of oxygenated functional groups and defects [68,73,105]. Nevertheless, the evidence for the high catalytic activity of TMOs immobilized on CNTs could be endorsed by the specific interaction among the nanoparticles of metal oxides and CNTs. Recently, we functionalized industrial-grade carboxylated multiwalled CNTs (IGMWCNT-COOH) with copper(II) ions. Cu(II) functionalized CNTs (IGMWCNT-COO-Cu) were then coated with a mixture of N-hydroxyphthalimide (NHPI) and ionic liquid (IL) 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium octylsulfate ([emim][OcOSO3]). The resultant catalyst was a blend of the solid catalyst with an ionic liquid layer (SCILL) and a supported ionic liquid phase (SILP) catalytic system. Hence, it was termed a SCILL-SILP hybrid catalytic system. The SCILL system was also synthesized by coating the [emim][OcOSO3] on IGMWCNT-COO-Cu. The catalytic activities of the produced systems were explored for the liquid-phase aerobic oxidation of ethylbenzene. For comparison, oxidation reactions were also performed for MWCNTs, IGMWCNT-COOH, and IGMWCNT-COO-Cu. The catalytic activity of IGMWCNT-COOH was lower than that of MWCNTs due to the presence of the carboxyl group, which harms the catalytic performance of CNTs in the reaction. After Cu(II) functionalization, the catalytic activity of industrial-grade carboxylated MWCNTs increased dramatically to 26.3% with NHPI as a co-catalyst. The increase in the catalytic activity of IGMWCNT-COO-Cu was credited to the metal ions, which accelerated the decomposition of hydroperoxides. The coating of ionic liquid over the IGMWCNT-COO-Cu, as in the SCILL system, covered the active sites and dramatically reduced the activity due to the high viscosity of the IL, which hampered radical production. The SCILL-SILP hybrid catalyst showed remarkable performance with a 27% conversion of ethylbenzene and 77% acetophenone selectivity. The higher selectivity towards acetophenone could be attributed to the solvent cage effect in the ionic liquid [83]. 5 Effect of CNTs purity on liquid phase oxidation of hydrocarbons Typical CNTs synthesis procedures yield randomly oriented, closed-ended structures, and the majority of these processes require high temperatures (>700 °C), resulting in considerable impurities in the final product [146]. These impurities affect the catalytic activity of CNTs. As a result, these impurities must be evaluated and removed or reduced from the produced CNTs. The influence of impurities of CNTs on the aerobic oxidation of hydrocarbons in the liquid phase was investigated by Zeynalov et al. [45]. The researchers synthesized MWCNTs using thermal pyrolysis of cyclohexane and examined their catalytic activity for cumene oxidation. The presence of metallic compounds within the structure of MWCNTs is responsible for stimulating the oxidation process, as determined through kinetic analysis. These metallic impurities were the residues of metal catalysts employed during the synthesis. These metals are typically converted into metal carbides, which are difficult to remove by employing mineral acids treatment. Consequently, due to the presence of these impurities in the MWCNTs, parallel reactions could occur according to the authors, with two processes occurring at the same time, MWCNTs + R• (RO2 •) → •MWCNTs-R (RO2) and ROOH + M@MWCNTs → RO• radicals (RO2 •). The branching of chain processes implies hydroperoxides inhibit alkyl and peroxide radicals from attaching to the carbon cage structure of CNTs, resulting in an autocatalytic mode of reaction. The aerobic oxidation of hydrocarbons in the liquid phase is extremely sensitive; even a trace amount of contaminant can prevent radical production or act as a free radical quencher and/or accelerate the oxidation process. For example, a modicum of Zn compounds (ZnCl2 and ZnBr2) completely inhibited cumene oxidation (10 mL cumene, 25 mL min−1 O2, 80 °C, 8 h.) catalyzed by CNTs (100 mg) [147]. Zn2+ inhibited catalytic oxidation in two possible ways, according to the mechanistic investigation. Initially, Zn2+ may strongly coordinate reactive oxygen species triggered by CNTs, raising the reaction's energy barrier. Next, the interaction between Zn2+ and radicals (RO• and ROO•) hinders the propagation events of the free radical chain. Conversely, the oxidation of cumene (80 °C, 8 h) was accelerated by utilizing a trace amount of Cu(OAc)2 (1 ppm of CNTs) in the presence of CNTs (100 mg) as a catalyst and oxygen as an oxidant (25 mL min−1) [148]. Cumene conversion increased from 38.5% to 54.2%, and alcohol selectivity increased from 25.1% to 44.7%, demonstrating that small amounts of Cu(OAc)2 could considerably alter the CNTs' reactivity and product selectivity. The promising effect was caused by the presence of adsorbed chlorine (Cl) on the surface of CNTs, which was adsorbed during the HCl washing process. Before using CNTs, HCl washing is a popular pretreatment technique. During the oxidation reaction, the adsorbed Cl on the CNTs surface became extremely unstable and reacted with Cu(OAc)2 to generate the Cu-Cl component, accelerating the decomposition of peroxides and modifying the activity and selectivity of the reaction. There are various recommended procedures for purifying CNTs, but acid treatment is widely accepted [149–151]. In this purification method, CNTs are oxidized with concentrated acids such as HNO3 or HNO3-H2SO4. The main drawbacks of this approach are that it frequently opens the ends of the nanotubes, cuts CNTs, damages a surface structure, and inserts oxygenated functional groups (-OH, -COOH, and -CO) into CNTs [152]. As stated above, these oxygenated functional groups have a deleterious impact on the catalytic activity of CNTs in the aerobic oxidation of hydrocarbons. 6 Prospects of CNTs in catalysis for hydrocarbon oxidation Pristine CNTs have shown remarkable performance in catalysis, including hydrocarbon oxidation reactions because of their unprecedented properties. Thanks to their elevated conductivity, which facilitates the electron transfer between radicals and themselves at the solid-liquid interface and enhances the rate of the reaction. The CNTs' conductivity can be further improved by doping a heteroatom such as nitrogen. The N-doping of CNTs can further accelerate the electron transfer between the intermediate radicals and surface carbon, thereby significantly enhancing the catalytic activity. The N-CNTs also accelerate the decomposition of peroxides, which are the key intermediates in hydrocarbon oxidation reactions, again increasing the catalytic performance. From the literature data, it can be deduced that a certain optimal loading of N in the CNTs increases the catalytic activity, and above that threshold limit the catalytic activity decreased. The type of doped N can also affect the catalytic function of the CNTs; for example, graphitic N is more effective for styrene oxidation, while pyrrolic N is more effective in producing active oxygen species. Nevertheless, N doping boosts the electrical properties of the CNTs, which is among the crucial factors that augment the catalytic activity of the CNTs, but still, at a higher amount of N in the CNTs, the catalytic activity decreases, which needs to be elaborated. Furthermore, the impact of the type of N doping in CNTs on their catalytic activity for oxidation reactions needs to be elaborated. The activity of other heteroatoms, for example, boron, phosphorus, etc., doped CNTs is also unexplored in hydrocarbon oxidation reactions. The surface functionalization of CNTs by the incorporation of various functional groups is another opportunity to modify the surface properties of CNTs to enhance the hydrophilicity or hydrophobicity. Attached surface functional groups can host other active catalysts or nanoparticles. The catalytic performance of the surface oxygenated groups for the hydrocarbon oxidation reactions is still ambiguous. The mechanism and negative catalytic activity of surface oxygenated functional groups for the liquid-phase hydrocarbon oxidation reactions need to be explored. Furthermore, various transition-metal-based catalysts, metal oxides, and other active catalysts can be linked with the surface functional groups and applied for liquid-phase hydrocarbon oxidation reactions in order to explore more effective catalysts. The elevated surface area and nanochannels of the CNTs provide another opportunity to tailor the catalytic properties. This is again an unexplored area in the liquid-phase aerobic hydrocarbon oxidation reactions. The high surface area has the capability to provide excellent support for other active catalysts. The nanochannels can encapsulate nanoparticles or other active catalysts. Thanks to the remarkable corrosion-resistant properties of CNTs which can protect the encapsulated metal nanocatalysts. Additionally, the use of confined metal nanoparticles in the CNTs as a catalyst will disperse homogenously in the reaction mixture without agglomerating, which ultimately enhances the catalytic activity. Furthermore, it is possible to combine the incredible properties of CNTs and the active catalyst to impart a synergistic effect to the resultant catalytic system. In our latest work [83], we have utilized Cu(II) modified CNTs as a catalyst and catalytic support for IL (SCILL system) and a mixture of IL and NHPI (SCILL-SILP hybrid catalytic system). We have combined the incredible properties of CNTs, NHPI, and IL to impart a synergistic effect to the resultant catalytic system. The TEM images with EDS analyses have been shown in Fig. 7, and the coating of the mixture of IL and NHPI over the CNTs (SCILL-SILP hybrid catalytic system) can be observed in Fig. 7 (C). Such a system can be produced by coating other ionic liquids with NHPI or other active catalysts, and the catalytic activity of the resultant system can be investigated. SILP and SCILL catalytic systems can also be produced by using CNTs and functionalized CNTs, which provide another path to investigate active catalytic systems for the aerobic oxidation of hydrocarbons in the liquid phase. CNTs and functionalized CNTs can be tailored to make them selective toward certain products in the hydrocarbon oxidation processes. For example, in our previous work, pristine CNTs were more selective toward hydroperoxides and after Cu(II) modification the CNTs were more selective toward acetophenone [83]. Similarly, Liao et al. found that pristine CNTs were more selective toward cumene hydroperoxide in cumene oxidation, while after N doping, N-CNTs were more selective towards benzyl propanol and acetophenone [62]. In the same way, certain functionalization of CNTs makes them more selective toward a specific oxidation product. Therefore, an investigation can also be carried out on the product distribution and effectiveness of functionalized CNTs in the liquid-phase hydrocarbon oxidation reactions in order to produce a task-specific catalyst. There are certain limitations regarding the industrialization of CNTs as a catalyst for the liquid-phase aerobic oxidation of hydrocarbons. For example, the production of high-quality CNTs on an industrial scale is still a costly and intricate process. Metal catalysts are used for the synthesis of CNTs, therefore, some of the metal impurities remain in CNTs [153]. As discussed earlier, even a trace amount of impurity can act as a free radical scavenger and halt the free radical oxidation reactions. Surface defects on the CNTs are also among the crucial drawbacks and realistic CNTs are not defect-free, containing several structural defects formed during their growth. The presence of these surface defects can influence the physical and chemical properties of the CNTs [154,155]. The other challenges in the production of homogeneous CNTs on large scales are, it is difficult to produce CNTs with the same diameter and length, and the batch-wise variation of CNTs during their production [153]. Nevertheless, CNTs are a greener alternative to the traditional homogeneous catalyst, providing many doors for future researchers to employ them as metal-free catalysts, functionalize them, or employ them as a support for other active catalysts for the liquid-phase aerobic hydrocarbon oxidation processes. 7 Conclusion CNTs as metal-free catalysts have shown elevated catalytic activity for the liquid-phase aerobic oxidation of hydrocarbons. Thanks to their elevated conductivity which augments the electron transfer among radicals and themselves at the solid-liquid interface to boost up the reaction rate. Their conductivity can be further enhanced by doping heteroatoms like nitrogen. Pristine CNTs are more selective towards hydroperoxides while after N-doping and or metal nanoparticles immobilization, their selectivity shifts towards AcPO. N-doped CNTs and metal-functionalized CNTs accelerate the decomposition of hydroperoxides and improve the catalytic activity. CNTs have proved to be an active and stable catalyst while being easily separable from the reaction mixture and reusable for multiple cycles. CNTs can be functionalized and or used as a support for other active catalysts to enhance the catalytic activity. Thanks to their robust metal support interaction, which enables them to combine with metal nanoparticles to synthesize the nanocomposite or nanohybrid catalyst. Furthermore, CNTs can be used to prepare SCILL, SILP, or combined SCILL-SILP hybrid catalytic systems for the oxidation of hydrocarbons in the liquid phase. coredata.dc:description: The liquid-phase aerobic oxidation of hydrocarbons to more valuable oxygenized compounds is among the most crucial industrial processes. Traditionally, these processes were executed by using a stoichiometric amount of various toxic oxidants with homogeneous catalysts of transition-metal salts and complexes, which results in the production of a gigantic amount of corrosive and noxious waste. Recently, carbon nanotubes have gained momentous importance as catalysts and catalytic support in various chemical processes because of their unprecedented properties. Few researchers have actually employed carbon nanotubes and functionalized carbon nanotubes as catalysts and catalytic support for the liquid-phase aerobic oxidation of hydrocarbons. This review specifically focused on the use of carbon nanotubes and functionalized carbon nanotubes as catalysts and catalytic supports in the liquid-phase aerobic oxidation of hydrocarbons. A plausible mechanism of the reaction has also been drawn while thoroughly reviewing the previously reported data. The impact of impurities in carbon nanotubes on their catalytic activity for the liquid-phase aerobic oxidation of hydrocarbons has also been discussed. It is observed from the literature that oxygenated carbon nanotubes have a negative effect on their catalytic activity for the liquid-phase aerobic oxidation of hydrocarbons, while nitrogen doping and/or metal nanoparticle immobilization, the surface electron transfer between the modified carbon nanotubes and radicals enhanced and improved the catalytic activity. Furthermore, the nitrogen-doped and/or metal-nanoparticle-incorporated carbon nanotubes accelerate the decomposition of hydroperoxides, which are key intermediates in the liquid-phase aerobic oxidation of hydrocarbons, thereby improving the overall catalytic activity.
coredata.dc:title: Carbon nanotubes as advanced catalysts and catalytic supports for the liquid-phase aerobic oxidation of hydrocarbons: A review
